title: Problem Overview
content:
**Erdős Problem #748: The Cameron-Erdős Conjecture**

**Question:** Is f(n) = 2^{(1+o(1))n/2} where f(n) counts sum-free subsets of {1,...,n}?

**Answer: YES**

Proved independently by Green (2004) and Sapozhenko (2003).
mathContext: A set A is sum-free if a = b + c has no solution with a,b,c ∈ A. The trivial lower bound 2^{n/2} comes from subsets of [n/2, n].

title: Sum-Free Set
content:
**IsSumFree A:**

A set A is sum-free if there are no a, b, c ∈ A with a = b + c.

Equivalently, A ∩ (A + A) = ∅.

Examples: {}, {1}, {2,3}, {4,5,6}, all odd numbers.

title: Equivalent Definition
content:
**sumFree_iff:**

IsSumFree A ↔ IsSumFree' A

The two formulations (a ≠ b + c vs b + c ≠ a) are equivalent.

title: Counting Function f(n)
content:
**f(n):**

The number of sum-free subsets of {1,...,n}.

This is the central object: how does f(n) grow with n?

OEIS A007865: f(1)=2, f(2)=3, f(3)=6, f(4)=9, f(5)=16, ...

title: Upper Half is Sum-Free
content:
**upperHalf_sumFree:**

Any subset of {n/2+1, ..., n} is sum-free.

**Proof:** If a, b ∈ [n/2+1, n], then a + b ≥ n + 2 > n, so a + b can't be in the set.

This gives the trivial lower bound f(n) ≥ 2^{n/2}.

title: Trivial Lower Bound
content:
**trivial_lower_bound:**

f(n) ≥ 2^{n/2} for n ≥ 2.

This is the easy direction: there are 2^{n/2} subsets of the upper half, all sum-free.

title: The Cameron-Erdős Conjecture
content:
**cameronErdosConjecture:**

f(n) = 2^{(1+o(1))n/2}

Formal statement: For all ε > 0, for large enough n,
(1-ε)·n/2 ≤ log₂(f(n)) ≤ (1+ε)·n/2

This says the trivial lower bound is essentially tight.

title: Green's Theorem (2004)
content:
**green_upper_bound:**

f(n) ≪ 2^{n/2}, i.e., f(n) ≤ C · 2^{n/2} for some constant C.

Proved in Bull. London Math. Soc. (2004).

This establishes the upper bound matching the lower bound up to constants.
mathContext: Green's proof uses sophisticated container methods and Fourier analysis.

title: Sapozhenko's Theorem (2003)
content:
**sapozhenko_upper_bound:**

Same result as Green, proved independently.

Published in Dokl. Akad. Nauk (2003).

title: Precise Asymptotic
content:
**precise_asymptotic:**

f(n) ~ c_n · 2^{n/2} where c_n depends on parity of n.

- c_even: constant for even n
- c_odd: constant for odd n

This is stronger than just f(n) = 2^{(1+o(1))n/2}.

title: Conjecture PROVED
Empty Set is Sum-Free
content:
**empty_sumFree:**

The empty set is trivially sum-free (no elements to form a sum).

title: Singletons are Sum-Free
content:
**singleton_sumFree:**

{x} is sum-free for x > 0 because x ≠ x + x = 2x.

title: Odd Numbers are Sum-Free
content:
**oddNumbers_sumFree:**

The set of odd numbers in [1,n] is sum-free.

**Proof:** odd + odd = even, but all elements are odd, so no sum can equal an element.

This gives another family of large sum-free sets.

title: Structure Theorem
content:
**structure_theorem:**

Most sum-free sets are "essentially" of two types:
1. Subsets of [n/2+1, n]
2. Subsets of odd numbers in [1, n]

Green's proof shows these two types dominate the count, explaining why f(n) ~ 2^{n/2}.

title: Schur Connection
content:
**schur_connection:**

The maximum size of a sum-free subset of [1,n] is ⌈n/2⌉.

This connects to Schur numbers in Ramsey theory: the minimum n such that any r-coloring of [1,n] has a monochromatic sum a = b + c.

title: Summary Theorem
Erdős Problem #748: PROVED
content:
**erdos_748:**

The main theorem: cameronErdosConjecture holds.

The number of sum-free subsets of {1,...,n} is 2^{(1+o(1))n/2}.
